pc_title: Association between posture and handball outcome
pc_abstract: Three out of ten characteristics were associated with handball outcome, and these related to the posture of the handballer (…).
pc_fulltext: The only characteristics that have a significant effect on handball outcome are the type of pressure experienced by the handball receiver and the handballer, and the posture of the handballer.

pc_title: Association between defense pressure to the handballer and handball outcome
pc_abstract: Three out of ten characteristics were associated with handball outcome, and these related to (…) the type of defensive pressure applied to the handballer (…).
pc_fulltext: The only characteristics that have a significant effect on handball outcome are the type of pressure experienced by the handball receiver and the handballer, and the posture of the handballer.

pc_title: Association between defense pressure to the receiver and handball outcome
pc_abstract: Three out of ten characteristics were associated with handball outcome, and these related to (…) the type of defensive pressure applied to the (..) the receiver of the handball.
pc_fulltext: The only characteristics that have a significant effect on handball outcome are the type of pressure experienced by the handball receiver and the handballer, and the posture of the handballer.

pc_title: Difference between Filters

pc_title: Higher step count with LFE filter
pc_fulltext: The LFE increased, on average, approximately 7500 steps/day compared to the normal filter (p < 0.001)

pc_abstract: The Movimente Programme was related to positive changes in adolescents’ perception of the school environment and social support from general and physical education teachers

pc_title: Time effect in quad thickness for FAIL
pc_abstract: Increases in quadriceps thickness (average of RF and VL) from pre- to post-intervention were similar for FAIL [0.181 cm (HDI: 0.119 to 0.243)] and RIR [0.182 cm (HDI: 0.115 to 0.247)].
pc_fulltext: Similar increases in quadriceps thickness were estimated for FAIL [0.181 cm (HDI: 0.119 to 0.243); pd = 100%] and RIR [0.182 cm (HDI: 0.115 to 0.247); pd = 100%] from pre- to post-intervention (Figure 3(c)).

pc_title: Time effect in quad thickness for RIR
pc_abstract: Increases in quadriceps thickness (average of RF and VL) from pre- to post-intervention were similar for FAIL [0.181 cm (HDI: 0.119 to 0.243)] and RIR [0.182 cm (HDI: 0.115 to 0.247)].
pc_fulltext: Similar increases in quadriceps thickness were estimated for FAIL [0.181 cm (HDI: 0.119 to 0.243); pd = 100%] and RIR [0.182 cm (HDI: 0.115 to 0.247); pd = 100%] from pre- to post-intervention (Figure 3(c)).

pc_title: Group difference in RF thickness
pc_abstract: Between-protocol differences in RF thickness slightly favoured RIR [−0.036 cm (HDI: −0.113 to 0.047)], but VL thickness slightly favoured FAIL [0.033 cm (HDI: −0.046 to 0.116)].
pc_fulltext: Moreover, we found an 81% probability (pd > TE = 42%) of slightly greater RF thickness when RT was performed to RIR (+7.38%) versus FAIL (+5.98%), but a 79% probability (pd > TE = 22%) of slightly greater VL thickness when RT was performed to FAIL (+7.95%) versus RIR (+6.59%).

pc_title: Group difference in VL thickness
pc_abstract: Between-protocol differences in RF thickness slightly favoured RIR [−0.036 cm (HDI: −0.113 to 0.047)], but VL thickness slightly favoured FAIL [0.033 cm (HDI: −0.046 to 0.116)].
pc_fulltext: Moreover, we found an 81% probability (pd > TE = 42%) of slightly greater RF thickness when RT was performed to RIR (+7.38%) versus FAIL (+5.98%), but a 79% probability (pd > TE = 22%) of slightly greater VL thickness when RT was performed to FAIL (+7.95%) versus RIR (+6.59%).

pc_title: Group difference in lower cognitive function between overweight and normal weight
pc_abstract: Results indicated that overweight adults had a lower rate of lower cognitive function than normal weight adults.
pc_fulltext: Compared to normal weight participants, overweight adults had a significantly lower rate of lower cognitive function in the total sample (adjusted OR: 0.82 (95% CI: 0.71–0.94))

pc_title: Group difference in lower cognitive function between overweight+high strength vs normal weight+normal strength
pc_abstract: Participants with overweight and high handgrip strength had a lower likelihood of lower cognitive function compared to those with normal weight and normal handgrip strength
pc_fulltext: Those with overweight and high handgrip strength had a significantly lower likelihood of lower cognitive function in the total sample, and the OR was 0.65 (95% CI: 0.51–0.82) after adjusting for the confounders

pc_title: Association between fatigue and mental quality of life
pc_abstract: Hierarchical regression analyses exposed fatigue to exert a significant negative influence on both mental and physical quality of life perceptions explaining 49% and 64% of the variance in these variables respectively
pc_fulltext: The final regression model (block 3) revealed to be significant and accounted for 64% of the variance in PQoL (M = 79.40, SD = 17.31), (R2 = 0.64, F(3,95) = 55.22, p < 0.01). Fatigue (M = 3.16, SD = 1.48) was found to be a significant negative predictor of PQoL, with standardised beta weights showing this predictor to have the strongest association to the outcome variable (ß = −.76, p < 0.01).

pc_title: Association between fatigue and physical quality of life
pc_abstract: Hierarchical regression analyses exposed fatigue to exert a significant negative influence on both mental and physical quality of life perceptions explaining 49% and 64% of the variance in these variables respectively
pc_fulltext: The final regression model (block 3) was significant and accounted for 49% of the variance in MQoL (M = 79.47, SD = 17.65), (R2 = 0.49, F(6, 92) = 14.53, p < .01).  Fatigue (ß = −0.62, p < .01) was found to be a significant negative predictor of MQoL, whilst physical activity enjoyment (ß = 0.19, p =.05) was a significant positive predictor of MQoL. Standardised beta weights showed fatigue to have the strongest association to the MQoL in the model.

pc_title: Association between standing broad jump and 800m performance
pc_abstract: In regression models adjusted for fat mass and maturity offset, standing broad jump, sit-ups and squats in 60 s were positively associated with the 800-m run test, while only standing broad jump remained significantly and positively associated with the 400-m run test.
pc_fulltext: In unadjusted models (Model 1), the 800-m run test was positively associated with standing broad jump, sit-ups in 60 s and squats in 60 s.When the model was adjusted for fat mass percentage and maturity offset (Model 2), similar positive associations remained.

pc_title: Association between sit ups and 800m performance
pc_abstract: In regression models adjusted for fat mass and maturity offset, standing broad jump, sit-ups and squats in 60 s were positively associated with the 800-m run test, while only standing broad jump remained significantly and positively associated with the 400-m run test.
pc_fulltext: In unadjusted models (Model 1), the 800-m run test was positively associated with standing broad jump, sit-ups in 60 s and squats in 60 s.When the model was adjusted for fat mass percentage and maturity offset (Model 2), similar positive associations remained.

pc_title: Association between squats and 800m performance
pc_abstract: In regression models adjusted for fat mass and maturity offset, standing broad jump, sit-ups and squats in 60 s were positively associated with the 800-m run test, while only standing broad jump remained significantly and positively associated with the 400-m run test.
pc_fulltext: In unadjusted models (Model 1), the 800-m run test was positively associated with standing broad jump, sit-ups in 60 s and squats in 60 s.When the model was adjusted for fat mass percentage and maturity offset (Model 2), similar positive associations remained.

pc_title: Association between standing broad jump and 400m performance
pc_abstract: In regression models adjusted for fat mass and maturity offset, standing broad jump, sit-ups and squats in 60 s were positively associated with the 800-m run test, while only standing broad jump remained significantly and positively associated with the 400-m run test.
pc_fulltext: For adjusted models, only standing broad jump was significantly associated with the 400-m run test,

pc_title: Group difference for rMSV for males at age 13
pc_abstract: Independent sample t-tests revealed that high-performing late juniors significantly outscored their lower-performing peers when they were early juniors on maximal swimming velocity (males aged 13–15 and females aged 12–14)
pc_fulltext: High-performing late junior males scored significantly higher on rMSV at age 13, 14 and 15 (all p < 0.001), rSI at age 13, 14 (p < 0.05) and 15 ((p < 0.01), and rST at age 13,14 and 15 (all p < 0.001), compared to lower-performing peers.

pc_title: Interaction effect of group and age on MSV in males
pc_abstract: Additionally, multilevel models showed faster rates of development for high-performing late juniors on maximal swimming velocity (males and females) and SI (males) compared to lower-performing peers throughout puberty (p < 0.05).
pc_fulltext: A significant interaction term would indicate a faster rate of development of high-performing swimmers compared to their lower-performing peers. In males, high-performing late junior swimmers showed significant faster progression over time on rSBT (+11%, p < 0.001), rMSV (+22%, p < 0.001) and rSI (+7%, p < 0.05) compared to lower-performing late junior swimmers.

pc_title: Interaction effect of group and age on MSV in females
pc_abstract: Additionally, multilevel models showed faster rates of development for high-performing late juniors on maximal swimming velocity (males and females) and SI (males) compared to lower-performing peers throughout puberty (p < 0.05).
pc_fulltext: A significant interaction term would indicate a faster rate of development of high-performing swimmers compared to their lower-performing peers. (…). In females, high-performing senior swimmers showed significant faster progression over time on rSBT (+12%, p < 0.001) and rMSV (+20% p < 0.01).

pc_title: Interaction effect of group and age on SI in males
pc_abstract: Additionally, multilevel models showed faster rates of development for high-performing late juniors on maximal swimming velocity (males and females) and SI (males) compared to lower-performing peers throughout puberty (p < 0.05).
pc_fulltext: A significant interaction term would indicate a faster rate of development of high-performing swimmers compared to their lower-performing peers. In males, high-performing late junior swimmers showed significant faster progression over time on rSBT (+11%, p < 0.001), rMSV (+22%, p < 0.001) and rSI (+7%, p < 0.05) compared to lower-performing late junior swimmers.

pc_title: Rater agreement in impule identification
pc_abstract: Results show an agreement in identifying impulses of J(R1, R2) = .80, while the agreement in classifying the impulse type (positive/negative) reached κ = .70
pc_fulltext: The cardinality of the union of the identified keyplays was 632, whereas that of the intersection was 503. This leads to an overall J(R1, R2) = .80, which corresponds to an agreement of 80% between raters.

pc_title: Rater agreement in impulse classification
pc_abstract: Results show an agreement in identifying impulses of J(R1, R2) = .80, while the agreement in classifying the impulse type (positive/negative) reached κ = .70
pc_fulltext: In 69 cases, raters showed a disagreement regarding the impulse type, which led to an overall moderate agreement of κ = .70,

pc_title: Descriptive share of errors by court zone
pc_abstract: Direct errors usually occur in the midcourt (56.4%), whereas most negative perturbations originate from the backcourt (40.0%).
pc_fulltext: Conversely, 24.7% of the negative keyplay impulses were played from the midcourt, with 56.4% of direct errors.

pc_title: Descriptive share of negative pertubation by court zone
pc_abstract: Direct errors usually occur in the midcourt (56.4%), whereas most negative perturbations originate from the backcourt (40.0%).
pc_fulltext: Here, 40.0% of negative keyplay impulses were played from the backcourt, with only 9.6% of direct errors.

pc_title: Descriptive share of winners by shot type
pc_abstract: In contrast to direct winners, mostly originating from a smash (45.5%), most positive perturbations are created by net shots (30.1%).
pc_fulltext: Second, while only 21.8% of the positive keyplay impulses were smashes, 45.5% of them were smashes for the winners, which could be explained by the specifics of these shots.

pc_title: Descriptive share of positive pertubations by shot type
pc_abstract: In contrast to direct winners, mostly originating from a smash (45.5%), most positive perturbations are created by net shots (30.1%).
pc_fulltext: First, 30.1% of positive keyplay impulses were net shots, but only 4.5% were winners.

pc_title: Group differences for plantarflexion angle
pc_abstract: Females landed with larger plantarflexion angles from 0–16% and smaller trunk flexion angles from 0–78%.
pc_fulltext: Females landed with larger plantarflexion angles from 0–16% of landing (SPM(t) = 2.656, p = 0.037) compared with males

pc_title: Group differences for trunk flexion angle
pc_abstract: Females landed with larger plantarflexion angles from 0–16% and smaller trunk flexion angles from 0–78%.
pc_fulltext: Females landed with smaller trunk flexion angles from 0–78% of landing (SPM(t) = 2.469, p = 0.007) compared with males

pc_title: Group differences for absolute TSM
pc_abstract: In females, absolute TSM were larger from 0–6% and smaller from 42–100%, and normalized TSM were larger from 0–8% and 26–42%.
pc_fulltext: Females landed with larger absolute total support moments from 0–6% of landing (SPM(t) = 2.984, p = 0.033) and smaller absolute total support moments from 42–100% of landing (SPM(t) = 2.984, p < 0.001) compared with males
pc_comments: I consider these two findings as one PC (e.g., they share the same test statistic)

pc_title: Group differences for normalized TSM
pc_abstract: Females had greater ankle contribution to the TSM from 14–15% and 29–35%,
pc_fulltext: Females landed with larger normalized total support moments from 0–8% of landing (SPM(t) = 3.021, p = 0.024) and 26–42% of landing (SPM(t) = 3.021, p = 0.002) compared with males
pc_comments: I consider these two findings as one PC (e.g., they share the same test statistic)

pc_title: Group difference in absolute peak TSM
pc_abstract: Females had (…) smaller absolute peak TSM,
pc_fulltext: The absolute peak total support moment was smaller in females compared with males (t54 = -5.046, p < 0.001

pc_title: Group difference in peak TSM timing
pc_abstract: [For] Females (…) the peak TSM occurred earlier.
pc_fulltext: The peak total support moment occurred earlier in landing for females (median = 36%) compared with males (median = 100%) (U = 632.5, Z = −2.891, p = 0.004, δ = -0.422).

pc_title: Reliability of right FAR
pc_abstract: Based on intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC3,1), the MPIs derived from 3D and LEOMO showed moderate agreement (0.50 < 0.75) for the right foot angular range (FAR); left foot angular range first quadrant (FARQ1); right leg angular range (LAR); and mean angle of the pelvis in the sagittal plane.
pc_fulltext: At best, the MPIs from the two systems showed moderate agreement levels, with the pelvic angle exhibiting the strongest correlations (ICC: 0.672), followed by the right FAR, left FARQ1, and right LAR (ICC range: 0.608 to 0.669).

pc_title: Descriptive mean of pre-school activity
pc_abstract: Completed diaries by 12–13 year-olds (n = 3,201) revealed that adolescents reported an average of 10.8 minutes of daily before-school physical activity (average segment length: 114 min), mostly classified as active transport (5.7 min).
pc_fulltext: Adolescents spent 10.8 minutes (girls: 9.2 minutes, boys: 12.5 minutes) on average in physical activity before school.

pc_title: Descriptive mean of pre-school activity by type
pc_abstract: Completed diaries by 12–13 year-olds (n = 3,201) revealed that adolescents reported an average of 10.8 minutes of daily before-school physical activity (average segment length: 114 min), mostly classified as active transport (5.7 min).
pc_fulltext: By activity classification, the major contributor to before-school physical activity time was transport-related activity (5.7 min, for both girls and boys)

pc_title: Descriptive mean of pre-school activity by location
pc_abstract: Most before-school physical activity occurred in a location other than home or school (6.1 min) and with peers (6.1 min)
pc_fulltext: For both boys and girls, most before-school physical activity occurred in a location other than home or school (6.0 min girls, 6.2 min boys)

pc_title: Descriptive mean of pre-school activity by co-presence
pc_abstract: Most before-school physical activity occurred in a location other than home or school (6.1 min) and with peers (6.1 min)
pc_fulltext: Most physical activity was accumulated in the presence of peers (5.1 min girls, 7.1 min boys)

pc_title: Descriptive proportion of boys without activity
pc_abstract: Notably, 51% of boys and 60% of girls did not report any before-school physical activity.
pc_fulltext: Forty percent of girls and 49% of boys reported engaging in at least one activity before school that was classed as physical activity

pc_title: Descriptive proportion of boys without activity
pc_abstract: Notably, 51% of boys and 60% of girls did not report any before-school physical activity.
pc_fulltext: Forty percent of girls and 49% of boys reported engaging in at least one activity before school that was classed as physical activity

pc_title: Association between gender and odds of particpating in activity
pc_abstract: Through two-part regression, we found that boys, adolescents from single-parent households, and those with longer before-school segments are more likely to report before-school physical activity compared to their counterparts.
pc_fulltext: An increase in the odds of engaging in physical activity was also observed for boys compared to girls (OR 1.27, p < .001, 95% CI: 1.17, 1.39)

pc_title: Association between parent status and odds of particpating in activity
pc_abstract: Through two-part regression, we found that boys, adolescents from single-parent households, and those with longer before-school segments are more likely to report before-school physical activity compared to their counterparts.
pc_fulltext: Adolescents with two parents in the home were 20% (OR 0.80, p = .001, 95% CI: 0.70, 0.91) less likely to engage in before-school physical activity than those without

pc_title: Association between segment length and odds of particpating in activity
pc_abstract: Through two-part regression, we found that boys, adolescents from single-parent households, and those with longer before-school segments are more likely to report before-school physical activity compared to their counterparts.
pc_fulltext: For every additional hour of segment length, the odds of engaging in before-school physical activity increase by 38% (OR 1.38, p = <.001, 95% CI: 1.27, 1.49).

pc_title: Association between shoe and peak dorsiflexion angle
pc_abstract: For shoe main effects, smaller peak dorsiflexion angle and internal peak plantarflexion moment and greater peak medial ground reaction force were found in the mid-cut but with no impact on knee mechanics.
pc_fulltext: There was a significant main effect of shoe for peak dorsiflexion angle (p = 0.038), indicating greater peak dorsiflexion with LT

pc_title: Association between shoe and  internal peak plantarflexion moment
pc_abstract: For shoe main effects, smaller peak dorsiflexion angle and internal peak plantarflexion moment and greater peak medial ground reaction force were found in the mid-cut but with no impact on knee mechanics.
pc_fulltext: A main effect of shoe was observed at the ankle, with greater internal peak plantarflexion moment in the LT (p = 0.019, Table 3, Figure 2(c)).

pc_title: Association between shoe and peak medial ground reaction force
pc_abstract: For shoe main effects, smaller peak dorsiflexion angle and internal peak plantarflexion moment and greater peak medial ground reaction force were found in the mid-cut but with no impact on knee mechanics.
pc_fulltext: A significant main effect of shoe was found for peak medial GRF (p = 0.017, Figure 3(a)),

pc_title: Association between limb and internal peak knee abduction moment
pc_abstract: For limb main effects, the internal peak knee abduction moment was greater in the dominant limb.
pc_fulltext: A significant main effect of limb was found for internal peak knee abduction moment (p = 0.014, Table 3, Figure 2(b))

pc_title: Interaction effect of shoe and limb on peak lateral ground reaction force
pc_abstract: Greater peak lateral ground reaction force was found in the interaction between the non-dominant limb and low-top.
pc_fulltext: A significant interaction was found for peak lateral GRF (F (1,17) = 8.083, p = 0.012)

pc_title: Mean difference between pre and post of fat tissue for UBE
pc_abstract: For UBE, mean pre to post differences were found on tissue fat (M = 0.35 ± 0.12%; CI95%diff = 0.10 to 0.59%; p = 0.007), region fat (M = 0.32 ± 0.11%; CI95%diff = 0.09 to 0.55%; p = 0.008), lean mass (M = 0.27 ± 0.01 kg; CI95%diff = 0.18 to 0.37 kg; p ≤ 0.0001), and total mass (M = 0.27 ± 0.05 kg; CI95%diff = 0.17 to 0.36 kg; p ≤ 0.0001).
pc_fulltext: Follow-up analyses showed for UBE a mean fat tissue pre to post difference of 0.35 ± 0.12% (CI95%diff = 0.10 to 0.59%; p = 0.007)

pc_title: Descriptive proportion of strength training experience
pc_abstract: Results showed that the majority of female players had participated in some form of S&C training in the past, with the majority believing that clubhead speed and carry distance were the primary golfing metrics which could be positively impacted.
pc_fulltext: Of the 157 respondents, 128 (81.5%) stated they had participated in some form of S&C or fitness training in the past

pc_title: Descriptive proportion of belief in training effect on clubhead sepeed
pc_abstract: Results showed that the majority of female players had participated in some form of S&C training in the past, with the majority believing that clubhead speed and carry distance were the primary golfing metrics which could be positively impacted.
pc_fulltext: Among the players who participated in the survey about the areas of golf performance that can be improved through S&C, the majority of responses emphasised “Club Head Speed” (n = 139, 25.7%) and “Carry Distance” (n = 130, 24%)

pc_title: Descriptive proportion of belief in training effect on carry distance
pc_abstract: Results showed that the majority of female players had participated in some form of S&C training in the past, with the majority believing that clubhead speed and carry distance were the primary golfing metrics which could be positively impacted.
pc_fulltext: Among the players who participated in the survey about the areas of golf performance that can be improved through S&C, the majority of responses emphasised “Club Head Speed” (n = 139, 25.7%) and “Carry Distance” (n = 130, 24%)

pc_title: Descriptive proportion of belief in movement mimicing for training
pc_abstract: Interestingly, 58% of the players believed that S&C training should mimic the movement of the golf swing,
pc_fulltext: Out of 131 total responses to “Do you believe that resistance training in a gym environment should replicate the golf swing?”, answers were divided between “Yes” (n = 76, 58%), and “No” (n = 55, 42%).

pc_title: Time effect for TQR
pc_abstract: A significant decrease was observed for TQR (F = 4.06; p = 0.01) and for WBQ (F = 5.37; p = 0.008) from T1 to T3.
pc_fulltext: A significant decrease was observed for TQR (F = 4.06; p = 0.01).
pc_comments: HR is no PC because no number given. TEST is no PC because of multiple values

pc_title: Time effect for WBQ

pc_fulltext: Similarly, a significant decrease was observed for WBQ (F = 5.37; p = 0.008).

pc_fulltext: The mean TDEE of the entire squad (n = 15) was 2882 ± 278 kcal/day

pc_title: Association between energy expenditure and FFM

pc_title: Descriptive mean of relative carbohydrate intake on rest days
pc_abstract: Carbohydrate intakes were 3.2 ± 0.7, 4.4 ± 1.1 and 5.3 ± 1.9 g/kg body mass for rest, training and match days, respectively, while weighted mean protein intake was 1.9 ± 0.4 g/kg body mass
pc_fulltext: In line, relative carbohydrate intakes were significantly higher on match days (5.3 ± 1.9 g/kg BM, p = 0.002) and training days (4.4 ± 1.1 g/kg BM, p = 0.003) when compared with rest days (3.2 ± 0.7 g/kg BM).

pc_title: Descriptive proportion of confidence in sensitivity
pc_abstract: Fifty-two per cent (n = 13) was confident in the sensitivity of their athlete self-report measures, but only 64% (n = 16), indicated their monitoring was underpinned by scientific evidence
pc_fulltext: Just over half (52%, n = 13) of respondents were quite or very confident in the sensitivity of their athlete self-report measures (ASRM) to detect meaningful change,

pc_title: Descriptive proportion of confidence in evidence base
pc_abstract: Fifty-two per cent (n = 13) was confident in the sensitivity of their athlete self-report measures, but only 64% (n = 16), indicated their monitoring was underpinned by scientific evidence
pc_fulltext: Respondents reported that scientific studies underpinned their ASRM in 64% (n = 16) of cases, with 24% (n = 6) disagreeing, and 12% (n = 3) neutral.

pc_title: Association between scientific base and feedback
pc_abstract: A scientific base was associated with improved athlete feedback (rS (23) = 0.487, p =0.014*) and feedback correlated with athlete monitoring adherence (rS (22) = 0.675, p =  <0.001**).
pc_fulltext: Where practitioners reported that their metrics had a scientific underpinning, there was also a correlation with improved feedback to the athletes (rS (23) = 0.487, p =0.014*)

pc_title: Association between feedback and adherence
pc_abstract: A scientific base was associated with improved athlete feedback (rS (23) = 0.487, p =0.014*) and feedback correlated with athlete monitoring adherence (rS (22) = 0.675, p =  <0.001**).
pc_fulltext: (…) with the provision of sufficient feedback also associated with improved athlete adherence (rS (22) = 0.675, p = <0.001**)

pc_title: Descriptive proportion of performance comprimising when non-adhering
pc_abstract: If athletes did not complete their monitoring, 52% (n = 13) of respondents felt performance might be compromised
pc_fulltext: Just over half of the respondents 52%, (n = 13) felt that athletes’ performance might be compromised if they did not complete their athlete monitoring, with 48%, (n = 12) disagreeing.

pc_title: Descriptive proportion of experience working with non-adhering successful elite athletes
pc_abstract: However, most respondents 56% (n = 14), had worked with internationally successful athlete(s) who did not complete their monitoring
pc_fulltext: Furthermore, 56% (n = 14) of respondents reported that they worked with internationally successful athletes (defined as those who had medalled at the Olympics, World Championships/Cups) who did not complete the monitoring required by their sporting organisation.

pc_title: Time effect for jump height
pc_abstract: Compared to baseline, jump height decreased at all timepoints following the STGC (all p < 0.05).
pc_fulltext: There was a significant main effect of time on jump height and leg stiffness (both p < 0.01, ηp2 = 0.08 and 0.01, respectively)
pc_comments: using the time effect instead of the post-hoc findings

pc_title: Interaction effect of time and condition
pc_abstract: Leg stiffness and cycling power output only decreased immediately following the STGC, with a 48% further decrease in cycling power output in hypoxia compared to normoxia (p < 0.05).
pc_fulltext: Post-hoc analysis revealed no difference between conditions on day 1 (95.8 ± 25.1 W) and day 3 (95.9 ± 23.7 W), whereas on day 2 cycling PO (39.4 ± 15.4 W) was significantly reduced by 46.8 ± 18.0% (range: 12.8–75.9%) in hypoxia compared to normoxia (p < 0.01, Figure 4a).
pc_comments: no exact number for PCs of leg stiffness and cycling power;

pc_title: Time effect for perceived fatigue
pc_abstract: Perceived fatigue, decreased sleep quality, and increased muscle soreness responses occurred on day 3 (p < 0.05)
pc_fulltext: There was a time effect in perceived fatigue, sleep quality, and muscle soreness (all p < 0.01, ηp2 = 0.20, 0.08 and 0.52, respectively).
pc_comments: using the time effect instead of the post-hoc findings

pc_title: Time effect for sleep quality
pc_abstract: Perceived fatigue, decreased sleep quality, and increased muscle soreness responses occurred on day 3 (p < 0.05)
pc_comments: using the time effect instead of the post-hoc findings

pc_title: Time effect for muscle soreness
pc_abstract: Perceived fatigue, decreased sleep quality, and increased muscle soreness responses occurred on day 3 (p < 0.05)
pc_comments: using the time effect instead of the post-hoc findings

pc_title: Time effect for peak knee flexion during walking
pc_abstract: After the marathon, there was a significant decrease in peak knee flexion (walking: p = 0.006; running: p = 0.006) and an increase in peak hip internal rotation (walking: p = 0.026; running: p = 0.015) during the stance phase of both walking and running compared to before the marathon.
pc_fulltext: Similarly, individuals after the marathon generated significantly less knee flexion during the walking task compared to before (Pre-Marathon: 15.3 ± 4.1°, Post-Marathon: 11.3 ± 5.0°, p = 0.006)

pc_title: Time effect for peak knee flexion during running
pc_abstract: After the marathon, there was a significant decrease in peak knee flexion (walking: p = 0.006; running: p = 0.006) and an increase in peak hip internal rotation (walking: p = 0.026; running: p = 0.015) during the stance phase of both walking and running compared to before the marathon.
pc_fulltext: The greatest decrease in peak knee flexion was observed during running (Pre-Marathon: 34.3 ± 3.7°, Post-Marathon: 27.0 ± 7.7°, p = 0.006)

pc_title: Time effect for peak hip internal rotation during walking
pc_abstract: After the marathon, there was a significant decrease in peak knee flexion (walking: p = 0.006; running: p = 0.006) and an increase in peak hip internal rotation (walking: p = 0.026; running: p = 0.015) during the stance phase of both walking and running compared to before the marathon.
pc_fulltext: Peak hip internal rotation showed significant changes, having increased to 8.0 ± 5.7° (compared to 4.7 ± 2.7°, p = 0.026) during walking and 11.1 ± 5.8° (compared to 6.8 ± 2.0°, p = 0.015) during running tasks after the marathon.

pc_title: Time effect for peak hip internal rotation during running
pc_abstract: After the marathon, there was a significant decrease in peak knee flexion (walking: p = 0.006; running: p = 0.006) and an increase in peak hip internal rotation (walking: p = 0.026; running: p = 0.015) during the stance phase of both walking and running compared to before the marathon.
pc_fulltext: Peak hip internal rotation showed significant changes, having increased to 8.0 ± 5.7° (compared to 4.7 ± 2.7°, p = 0.026) during walking and 11.1 ± 5.8° (compared to 6.8 ± 2.0°, p = 0.015) during running tasks after the marathon.

pc_title: Group difference for ST between periods
pc_abstract: A significant decrease in the ST during 2016–2022 (p < 0.001) in athletes of all ages and both sexes overall was reported.
pc_fulltext: A significant decrease in ST was found between 2016–2022 and 2009–2015 (average difference: −8.8 (4.9–12.7), effect size: 0.12 (0.06–0.17), p < 0.001)
pc_comments: no exact or single numbers for all other claims
